chunks.en: Can anyone explain the fun of building games?

During the Spring Festival, I unintentionally downloaded a bunch of these games, including Don't Starve, Terraria, Ark: Survival Evolved, and many others with names I can't even pronounce in English. I'm not denying the beauty of these game designs, but I really can't experience it.

chunks.en: The gameplay usually starts with chopping grass, chopping grass, chopping grass, picking fruits, picking fruits, picking fruits, and then encountering a small boss for a battle where you might die or survive. If you die, you have to build up your tools to increase damage and chop him down. Then you have more and more tools, more and more items, and you keep fighting stronger monsters in a repeating cycle. It's not as tiring as going to work or school. It's no different from traditional RPGs, but at least they have a storyline, like Witch Spring 4 (where the amount of plot is greater than the number of monsters, if you count the grass at the beginning of the building game as monsters). If the gameplay is about building, why not play LEGO (there's a game version too) instead of chopping grass? If the focus is on survival, there are so many horror games or shooting tactics games. In short, my feeling is that it's exhausting.

Sandbox games often don't have any problems that must be solved. There's no demon king to defeat, no princess to save, no Templars, no dragons, no ancient gods, no Holy Grail, no mechs, no cybernetics. Minecraft just needs to survive, Terraria just needs to survive, and Don't Starve just needs to survive. If you just stand there, the resources already on the map are enough for you to stand there until the end of time.
It's the players themselves who are curious about the world and want to explore it, and then they encounter various problems. In the process of trying to solve these problems, new problems arise.
In comparison, other games will directly throw these problems at the player, telling you to find a certain NPC, to obtain a certain item, to defeat a certain enemy.

But because of this, the freedom of these games is far less than that of sandbox games. Players can only complete a certain task, and almost all events in this process are pre-set, and all problems only offer a few solutions.

In a sandbox, players can act according to their own ideas. For example, when you want to build a shelter, how tall, how big, how many floors, how many doors, what color, what shape, staggered or uniform, you can freely use your imagination and creativity.
When we see videos of various speedruns, fancy combos, or no-damage playthroughs, we say it's cool, marveling at the player's skills and operations - he can actually pull off operations that I can't!

And when we see the various wonders in sandbox games, we say it's cool, marveling at the player's whimsy - why is my shelter a square coffin room, while his shelter is cleverly designed and full of beauty?

As the name of sandbox games describes, this is playing with sand. Think about childhood, when you were happily stacking blocks or playing with sand, looking at plastic blocks and sand. It's just that now we have more advanced, interactive, intelligent building blocks made of 0s and 1s to play with.

'If you die, you have to build up your tools to increase damage and chop him down.' If you can only play like this, it's really boring, but good sandbox upgrades offer game mechanics, not damage stats.

For example, if you can't beat a monster in Don't Starve, you can lure other monsters to fight each other, you can make bombs to kill them in their sleep, you can build walls and traps to fight them, or you can raise animals to help you fight. Discovering these methods is a pleasure in itself.
I once read a philosophy book that started by saying: There are two types of games in the world, one is to end the game, and the other is to keep the game going.
Perhaps building games with stronger sandbox attributes can meet the 'fun' you're talking about, such as Kerbal Space Program and space simulators.
Many flight enthusiasts think that 'fun' should refer to physical properties, because such games are the most scientific.
It should be called a sandbox game.
The main selling point of open-world games is to weaken the constraints of the plot and explore the gameplay according to your own preferences.

Sandbox games are more free than ordinary open-world games. The game only provides a general worldview and tools, and players can build and explore according to their own ideas. The plot is basically unnecessary.
As for LEGO, traditional physical LEGOs are just building, but they lack interaction with the world.

For example, if you build a house in a sandbox game, it can resist monster attacks, but LEGO can only put a few LEGO minifigures to play house or take pictures; larger-scale LEGO works are too expensive.
As for LEGO video games, most of them are still story-driven. It seems that Lego: Worlds is a sandbox-type game, but I haven't paid attention to it, so I don't know how it is.
This type of game is for players who like to collect and explore, and some of them challenge the speed of difficulty.

Anyway, to each their own. I don't like playing 3A RPGs, such as this year's Baldur's Gate 3. It feels like watching a novel or a movie. It's tiring to play for hundreds of dollars. It's better to just watch a movie or read a novel.
On the one hand, you can continuously get positive feedback, such as collecting more and more items, stronger and stronger equipment, or gradually building a completed house.

On the other hand, this process is relatively relaxing, you can play at a very slow pace, you don't need to spend too much energy, at most you need to process a lot of information and familiarize yourself with the game content when you first come into contact with the game.
On the other hand, you can stop this type of game whenever you want, unlike story-driven games where you have to finish the story to complete the game.
Does the original poster think Palworld is fun?

I'm curious about what the game mechanics are, what I can do in the game, whether I can use what I've learned to make what I imagine, whether this and that can be achieved. I used to love playing Minecraft because I liked all kinds of exploration.
Later, I gradually found that I was no longer curious about these things, and I didn't like playing it very much.

Maybe the OP is just not used to games with a similar high degree of freedom, aimless, and subconsciously thinks that this is a game, there should be a task list, I should complete these, but suddenly there are none, which leads to an increase in mental burden.

It would be best if there was a game that was the same as reality, where I could freely play one of the billions of people in it, complete work, slowly pass time, and see the world change, but in the game.
I think I've discovered that there are ads at the bottom of this website for the first time. Clicking on it leads to a community Minecraft server. ğŸ˜“ Speechless.
It's all about getting others to worship you. Before, I played MC and my fan group was full of 2,000 people, but unfortunately I couldn't monetize it.
It's just a kind of companionship, the content of the game doesn't matter.
Some people can delay their satisfaction until two or three years later when their entire save is filled with magnificent and original wonders of the world.
Some people can't even last until the next day to make a campfire and they don't want to play anymore.
It's really not fun to play alone, it's hard to immerse yourself in it.
Terraria focuses more on exploration. The fun is in gradually upgrading to fight better bosses with better equipment and go to more places. The game content is not very repetitive.

chunks.en: The construction part is mostly just building a battle arena when fighting bosses. It doesn't take a few minutes to build a jail for the NPCs to live in.
I only like these two: "Minecraft", also known as 'other people's world'.
"Besiege", also known as 'spectating'.
How much fun there is depends on: your understanding of the game's characteristics and 'features' (bugs); your imagination; other people's imagination.

Ten years ago, I was very addicted to building various automated production lines in Minecraft, but when I quit the game and thought about my bills, mortgage, and pitiful salary at the time, I still felt a little lost. It's much more difficult to meet survival needs in reality than in the game.

To help understand various ideas of software engineering, I play Factorio, which tests the design ability of workflow and the design ability of architecture, which is very helpful for me to understand various ideas of software engineering.
